[[Western Association of Schools and Colleges|WASC]]. |website = [http://www.csupomona.edu/ http://www.csupomona.edu/] |coor = {{Coord|34|03|23|N|117|49|18|W|type:edu_region:US-CA|display=inline,title}} |logo = [[File:CalPolyLogotype.PNG|210px]] |footnotes = All enrollment figures are as of September 1, 2010 }} '''California State Polytechnic University, Pomona''', or '''Cal Poly Pomona''', is a [[public university]] located in [[Pomona, California|Pomona]], [[California]], [[United States]]. It is one of [[Cal Poly (disambiguation)|two polytechnics]] in the 23-member [[California State University]] system. Cal Poly Pomona began as a satellite campus of the California Polytechnic School (today known as [[California Polytechnic State University|Cal Poly San Luis Obispo]]) in 1938 when a completely equipped school and farm in the city of [[San Dimas, California|San Dimas]] were donated by Charles Voorhis and his son [[Jerry Voorhis]]. The satellite campus grew further in 1949 when a [[Ranch|horse ranch]] in the neighboring city of Pomona, which had belonged to [[Will Keith Kellogg]], was acquired. Cal Poly Pomona, then known as âCal Poly Kellogg-Voorhisâ, and Cal Poly San Luis Obispo continued operations under a unified administrative control until they became independent from each other in 1966. Cal Poly Pomona currently offers multiple educational programs in [[California State Polytechnic University, Pomona academics|9 academic units]] and enrolls over 22,000 students as of fall 2010. The university is one among a small group of [[Institute of Technology (United States)#Polytechnic Universities|polytechnic universities in the United States]] which tend to be primarily devoted to the instruction of technical arts and applied sciences. Once known strictly as a commuter school, in recent years Cal Poly Pomona has undertaken an effort to increase its academic standings while also evolving into a more traditional university. The university has raised admissions standards, increased on-campus student residences, built new facilities and expanded [[U.R. Bronco|its undergraduate research opportunities]]. Its sports teams are known as the [[Cal Poly Pomona Broncos]] and play in the [[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]] [[Division II (NCAA)|Division II]] as part of the [[California Collegiate Athletic Association]] (CCAA). Kellogg]].]] Events leading to the foundation of present-day Cal Poly Pomona began with the demise of the Voorhis School for Boys in [[San Dimas, California]] and its acquisition by the [[San Luis Obispo, California|San Luis Obispo]]-based California Polytechnic School in 1938.{{Harvnb|Pflueger|1999|p=41.}} The California Polytechnic School was founded as a [[Vocational education in the United States|vocational]] [[high school]] when California Governor [[Henry Gage]] signed the Polytechnic School Bill on March 8, 1901 after its drafting by school founder Myron Angel.{{Harvnb|Pflueger|1999|p=18.}} Voorhis School, on the other hand, had been established in 1928 as a private vocational school which provided [[Primary education|elementary schooling]] for underprivileged boys and operated under the [[Christianity|Christian]] religious principle, "education coupled with the Kingdom of God".{{cite web |title= New president takes the reins at Cal Poly Pomona |url= http://www.allbusiness.com/north-america/united-states-california/929276-1.html |work= Inland Empire Business Journal |accessdate= 2010-01-02}}{{Harvnb|Pflueger|1999|p=44.}} Its founder Charles B. Voorhis and [[Head teacher|headmaster]] [[Jerry Voorhis]] maintained the school opened throughout the worst years of the [[Great Depression]] but persistent economic pressures forced them to transfer control to Cal Poly in San Luis Obispo in 1938.{{Harvnb|Pflueger|1999|p=45.}} Hence, Voorhis School became the Cal Poly-Voorhis Unit and its educational offerings were raised to the same level as Cal Poly SLO.âs âthen a two-year college.{{cite web |url= http://www.alumni.calpoly.edu/alumniinfo/university-history.html |archiveurl= http://web.archive.org/web/20080616082843/http://www.alumni.calpoly.edu/alumniinfo/university-history.html |archivedate= 2008-06-16 |title= University History |publisher=[[California Polytechnic State University]] | accessdate=2010-02-04}} The entire horticulture program was moved to the new satellite campus and the two units operated as one institution spanning two locations under the leadership of president Julian McPhee.{{cite web| url=http://www.csupomona.edu/~library/specialcollections/history/sandimas.html| title=Cal Poly San Dimas?| first=Allen| last=Ferreira| year=1985| publisher=California State Polytechnic University, Pomona |accessdate=2010-01-31}} During [[World War II]] most of the student body was called to active duty, enrollment declined and the campus closed in 1943.{{Harvnb|Pflueger|1999|p=51.}} Reopening after the war, Cal Poly-Voorhis Unit operated in San Dimas until 1956 when it moved to [[Will Keith Kellogg]]âs former [[Ranch|horse ranch]] in the neighboring city of [[Pomona, California]].{{cite web | title= Heritage and History at Cal Poly Pomona | url= http://www.csupomona.edu/cpp_heritage.php| publisher= California State Polytechnic University, Pomona | accessdate=2010-11-11}} Acknowledging its Kellogg legacy, Cal Poly-Voorhis Unit changed its name to Cal Poly Kellogg-Voorhis Unit and offered six programs in agriculture. The inaugural class of 1957 at the new campus consisted of 57 students graduating with Bachelorâs degrees in a ceremony held at the Rose Garden in Pomona and religious services at Voorhis Chapel in San Dimas.{{cite web | title= California State Polytechnic University, Pomona - Historical Development | url= http://www.csupomona.edu/~academic/catalog/gen_info/Univ_Admin.pdf| publisher= California State Polytechnic University, Pomona | format=PDF | accessdate=2008-11-14}}{{Harvnb|Pflueger|1999|p=103.}} Also in 1957, Cal Poly Kellogg-Voorhis introduced the [[Cal Poly Pomona College of Engineering|College of Engineering]], the second academic unit after the [[Cal Poly Pomona College of Agriculture|College of Agriculture]].{{Citation | title = University Ranks Fifth in West, Engineering Program Ninth in Nation by U.S. News & World Report | newspaper = PolyTrends | page = 2 | year = 2003 | url = http://www.csupomona.edu/~advancement/publications/polytrends_fall03.pdf | accessdate = January 31, 2010}} The [[California Master Plan for Higher Education]] added the two Cal Poly campuses to the new California State College system in 1961 and Cal Poly Kellogg-Voorhis Unit opened its doors for the first time to 329 female students. President McPhee retired in 1966, and the two Cal Poly split becoming two different and independent universities. The partnership between the two campuses remains with their involvement in the annual [[Cal Poly Universities Rose Float]].{{Harvnb|Pflueger|1999|pp=133–134.}} To better reflect its new ties to the State College system, Cal Poly Kellogg-Voorhis changed its name to âCalifornia State Polytechnic College, Kellogg-Voorhisâ in 1966 and became the 16th campus to officially join. Robert C. Kramer assumed presidency of the independent campus in 1966 (second overall as the university recognizes McPhee as its first) and California State Polytechnic College, Kellogg-Voorhis finally adopted its present-day name California State Polytechnic University, Pomona on June 1, 1972.{{cite web|url=http://www.csupomona.edu/~library/specialcollections/oralhistory/ |title=Voices From Our Past - Cal Poly Pomona Oral History |publisher=California State Polytechnic University, Pomona |date=2009-03-18 |accessdate=2010-04-30}}{{cite web|url=http://www.calstate.edu/pa/info/milestones.shtml |title=CSU | Public Affairs | Historic Milestones |publisher=[[California State University]] |date=2009-03-18 |accessdate=2010-04-30}} In 1998, Cal Poly Pomona received criticism when it planned to grant an honorary degree to [[Robert Mugabe]]. 2010-09-11}} ===Name=== {{Dablink|See also: [[California State University#Campus naming conventions|Campus naming conventions in the CSU]] and [[California Polytechnic State University#Name]].}} The campus' office of public affairs recognizes two official names for the university: "California State Polytechnic University, Pomona" and "Cal Poly Pomona".{{cite news| url= http://www.csupomona.edu/~publicaffairs/graphics/nomenclature.shtml| title=Identity| publisher= Office of Public Affairs at Cal Poly Pomona| accessdate=2010-02-01}} However, "Cal Poly" has also been In the years when the [[University of California]] was in charge of Kellogg's donated estate in Pomona (1932â1943), the names "University of California, W.K. Kellogg Institute" and "W.K. Kellogg Institute of Animal Husbandry University of California, Pomona", came into use to describe the site.{{Harvnb|Parkinson|2001|p=213.}}{{Harvnb|Parkinson|2001|p=204.}} Although Cal Poly Pomona is now part of the [[California State University]], its naming convention does not follow that of most campuses within the system ([[E.g.#exempli gratia|e.g.]] the CSU campus in [[San Diego]] bears the full official name "[[San Diego State University]]" and the CSU campus in [[Fullerton, California|Fullerton]] uses the name "[[California State University, Fullerton]]").{{cite web| title=The New SDSU Graphic Identity System| url=http://advancement.sdsu.edu/marcomm/logo/SDSU_User_Manual_1.3.pdf| format=PDF| work= [[San Diego State University]]| page=4| accessdate=2011-03-28}}{{cite web| title=Editorial Style| url= http://www.fullerton.edu/identity/downloads/guidelines/editorial-style.pdf| format=PDF| work= [[California State University, Fullerton]]| page=3| accessdate=2011-03-28}} Thus, "Pomona State University" and "California State University, Pomona" are seldom used and not in the university's graphic standard's manual. Nonetheless, Cal Poly Pomona's [[web page]] is http://www.csupomona.edu/. ==Campus== {{Location map | Los Angeles | float = right | caption = Location of Cal Poly Pomona in the [[Los Angeles metropolitan area]]. | label = Cal Poly Pomona | mark = Green sphere.png | marksize = 10 | lat_deg = 34.05639 | lon_deg = -117.82167 }} Cal Poly Pomona is situated in [[Pomona, California|Pomona]], a largely suburban city that is part of the [[Los Angeles metropolitan area]]. The city of Pomona is located in the eastern portion of [[Los Angeles County]] and borders the neighboring [[San Bernardino County|county of San Bernardino]] to the east. The universityâs {{convert|1438|acre|ha|sp=us}} campus{{cite web |url= http://www.csupomona.edu/~jskoga/physicalcalpoly/ |title= The Physical Cal Poly Pomona |author= James S. Koga |publisher= California State Polytechnic University, Pomona |accessdate= 2008-08-27}} make it the second largest in the [[California State University]] system,{{cite web |url=http://www.aaiep.org/schools/show/189/cal_poly_english_language_institute |title=Cal Poly English Language Institute |publisher=American Association of Intensive English Programs |accessdate=2010-08-22}} a figure which includes various facilities scattered throughout [[Southern California]] such as a {{convert|53|acre|ha|sing=on}} ranch in [[Santa Paula, California]], {{convert|25|acre|ha|sing=on}} campus at the former Spadra Landfill (now known as "Spadra Ranch"),{{cite web | url= http://www.csupomona.edu/~plantsci/facilities.shtml | title=Department Facilities | publisher= California State Polytechnic University, Pomona| accessdate=2008-09-17}}{{cite web | url=http://www.lacsd.org/about/solid_waste_facilities/spadra/default.asp | title=Spadra Landfill (Post Closure Activities) | publisher=Sanitation Districts of Los Angeles County | accessdate=2011-03-26}} and the [[Neutra VDL Studio and Residences]] in [[West Los Angeles]]. In addition, the main Pomona campus is home to a 31-hectare (0.31 km2) [[Nature reserve|ecological reserve]] known as the Voorhis Ecological Reserve.{{cite web| url=http://www.csupomona.edu/~jcclark/classes/bot343/project1.html| title=Project: Flora of Cal Poly Pomona| last=Clark| first= Curtis| publisher=California State polytechnic University, Pomona| year=2005| accessdate=2011-03-28}} Although part of the [[Los Angeles metropolitan area]], the university is in close proximity to two other large metropolitan and culturally-defined regions, the [[Inland Empire (California)|Inland Empire]] and [[Orange County, California|Orange County]].{{cite web| url=http://www.wilkinguge.com/research/inland-empire-insights.php| title=Inland Empire Insights| work=Wilkin Guge Marketing| year=2008| accessdate=2011-03-28}} The university has a tier 1 area, defined as a geographical admissions region surrounding the campus, roughly bounded by the [[San Gabriel Mountains]] to the north, the city of [[Chino Hills, California|Chino Hills]] to the south, [[Interstate 605]] to the west, and [[Interstate 15]] to the east.{{cite web |url= http://www.insidesocal.com/educationnow/2010/02/cal-poly-requiring-certain-fre.html |title= Department Facilities |publisher= [[Los Angeles Newspaper Group]] |accessdate=2010-08-22}} Cal Poly Pomona's campus buildings vary in age and style from the [[Mission Revival Style architecture|Mission Revival]] Kellogg Horse Stables and the Kellogg House (suggesting the [[Spanish architecture#Spanish Colonial architecture|Spanish colonial architectural heritage]] of [[Southern California]]) built in the 1920s; the modernist box-like portion of [[California State Polytechnic University, Pomona, Library|the library]] completed in 1969; to contemporary dormitories, engineering, science and library-expansion facilities completed in the early 21st century.{{sfn|CPSUSLO|2001|p=68}} Leisure and recreational locations include a [[rose garden]] which dates back to the Kellogg horse ranch years; the Kellogg House designed by Los Angeles-based architects Charles Gibbs Adams, [[Myron Hunt]] and Harold Coulson Chambers in the 1920s; and a {{convert|1.3|acre|ha}} [[Japanese garden]] built in 2003 and designed by [[Takeo Uesugi]].{{cite web| url= https://digital.lib.washington.edu/architect/structures/3836/| title=Kellogg, W.K., Ranch House, Pomona, CA| publisher=[[University of Washington]]| accessdate=2010-08-22}}{{cite web| url=http://www.jgarden.org/gardens.asp?ID=642| title=George and Sakaye Aratani Japanese Garden at Cal Poly Pomona| last=Cheetham| first=Robert |publisher=Japanese Garden Research Network, Inc.| accessdate=2010-08-22}} Kelloggâs House features grounds which were initially landscaped by Charles Gibbs Adams but were later completed by [[Florence Yoch & Lucile Council]]. Cal Poly Pomona's George and Sakaye Aratani Japanese Garden is one among four under management by institutions of higher education in the County of Los Angeles, the other being the Earl Burns Miller Japanese garden at [[California State University, Long Beach|Cal State Long Beach]], the Hannah Carter Japanese garden at [[University of California, Los Angeles|UCLA]], and the Shinwa-En Garden at [[California State University, Dominguez Hills|Cal State Dominguez Hills]].{{cite web |url=http://www.la.us.emb-japan.go.jp/e_web/e_m06_29.htm |title=Japanese Gardens in Southern California and Arizona |publisher=Consulate General of Japan in Los Angeles |accessdate=2011-03-31}} At the center of the campus and atop Horsehill are the buildings comprising the [[Collins College of Hospitality Management]] and Kellogg West, a hotel and conference center and home of the student/faculty-run Restaurant at Kellogg Ranch. At the north edge of the campus is the Voorhis Ecological Reserve, which serves as a [[wildlife corridor]] containing [[Coastal Sage Scrub]] and [[Quercus agrifolia|Coast Live Oak]] trees among others. Contrasting some of these architecturally prominent facilities, there are various [[portable building]]s on campus which are used to accommodate the growing enrollment of recent decades. Cal Poly Pomona operates the [[International Polytechnic High School]], a college preparatory high school housed entirely in portable buildings which stand on what used to be a parking lot. As of June 2010, [[financial audit]]or [[KPMG]] valued Cal Poly Pomona's [[asset|total asset]]s at $577.3 million [[United States dollar|US Dollars]].{{cite web| url= http://www.csupomona.edu/~fas/docs/09_10_financial_statements.pdf|title= Financial Statements| date=2011-01-28| work=[[KPMG]]| publisher=California State Polytechnic University, Pomona| pages=6â41| format=PDF| accessdate=2011-09-14}} Cal Poly Pomona's dominant landmark is a [[Futurist architecture|futurist-styled]] administrative facility known as the [[CLA Building]] which was designed by [[Antoine Predock]] and opened in 1993. The buildingâs peculiar shape (standing out by a triangular-shaped âskyroomâ atop its eight-story tower {{cite web|url=http://californiawatch.org/watchblog/iconic-cal-poly-pomona-building-poses-earthquake-hazard |title=Iconic Cal Poly Pomona building poses earthquake hazard |author=Erica Perez |date=March 23, 2010 |publisher=[[California Watch]] |accessdate=22 August 2010}}) has become a symbol of the university; in addition, its close location to film studios based in the [[Hollywood]] borough of Los Angeles have prompted its inclusion in motion pictures such as ''[[Gattacca]]'' and ''[[Impostor (film)|Impostor]]''.{{cite news|url=http://www.csupomona.edu/~polycentric/campus_news/123101-imposter.shtml|title=CLA Building Gets Big Screen Treatment as Dimension Filmsâ "Impostor" Hits Theaters | date=2001-12-31 | work=polycentric | accessdate=2011-03-28}} {{wide image-2|CLA Portrait.jpg|700px|Panorama of the [[CLA Building]] at Cal Poly seen from the engineering meadow. The Japanese garden is at the lower left of the image.|75%|right}} ===Academic and research facilities=== The [[W. K. Kellogg Arabian Horse Center]] is an academic and research facility serving one of the 22 terms and conditions to the donation of the Kellogg ranch by maintaining Kelloggâs purebred [[Arabian horse]]s and their breeding program. Another academic facility highlighting the Kellogg legacy is the Horse Stables (also known as University Plaza) which contains a small research library specializing in equine studies along with offices for student services and various campus organizations. Conceived in 1995 by then university president, Bob H. Suzuki, and initially financed by [[NASA]] and the [[Economic Development Administration]], the Innovation Village is a {{convert|65|acre|ha|adj=on}} public/private partnership research and business facility at the southern edge of the campus. Major tenants include the [[American Red Cross]], [[Southern California Edison]], and the [[NASA]] Commercialization Center.{{cite web|url=http://www.innovationvillage.org/generalinfo.aspx|title=General Information|publisher= Innovation Village|accessdate= 2011-03-03}} The project is currently at the halfway mark of building and leasing {{convert|1000000|sqft|m2}} of the projected total building space. Once complete, it is estimated that the project would employ 2000 to 3000 people and provide half a billion dollars of economic benefits to the local, regional and state economies.{{cite news|url=http://www.labusinessjournal.com/news/2005/dec/19/innovation-park-puts-cal-poly-pomona-on-biotech/|title=Innovation Park Puts Cal Poly Pomona on Biotech Map|work=[[Los Angeles Business Journal]]|accessdate=2011-03-03}} ===Campus sustainability and transportation=== The university has actively sought to reduce carbon emissions and energy usage on campus. In November 2007, Cal Poly Pomona became a signatory member of the [[Campus Carbon Neutrality#American College and University Presidents' Climate Commitment|American College & University Presidents Climate Commitment]].{{cite web| url= http://acupcc.aashe.org/ip/195/ |title= Implementation Profile for California State Polytechnic University-Pomona |month= July, 13 |year= 2009 |publisher= [[Campus Carbon Neutrality#The Association for the Advancement of Sustainability in Higher Education|Association for the Advancement of Sustainability in Higher Education]] |accessdate= 2010-08-22}} Among other things, this committed the university to ensure that within one year, it would purchase or produce at least 15% of the institution's electric consumption from [[Renewable resource|renewable sources]]. The university, along with other members in the CSU, is also a member of the [[California Climate Action Registry]].{{cite web| url= http://www.climateregistry.org/about/members.html |title= Members |month= December, 15 |year= 2009 |publisher= [[California Climate Action Registry]] |accessdate= 2010-08-22}} and lists on ''[[The Princeton Review]]'s'' ''Guide to 286 Green Colleges''.{{cite web|title=286 Green Colleges (Full List)|url=http://www.princetonreview.com/green-schools-full-list.aspx|publisher=[[The Princeton Review]] in partnership with the U.S. [[Green Building Council]]|accessdate=15 April 2011}} Cal Poly Pomona's institute for sustainability education is the [[Lyle Center for Regenerative Studies]]. The center was built adjacent to an old landfill and conducts research in the areas of sustainable technology and agriculture. As an example of [[Cradle to Cradle Design]], it uses solar-powered dormitories, aquaculture ponds, and organic gardens while providing an environmentally-sustainable housing accommodation for 22 graduate students. In 2010, with the installation of a 210,000 kW hours [[Concentrated Photovoltaics|CPV]] system by [[Amonix]], the center became the first [[carbon neutral]] facility in the [[California State University]] system.[http://polycentric.csupomona.edu/news_stories/2010/09/lylecenter-carbon-neutral-amonix-systems.html Lyle Center Goes Carbon Neutral with Amonix Solar Energy Systems] polycentric The center is part of Agriscapes, a {{convert|40|acre|ha|adj=on}} research project that showcases environmental and agricultural sustainable practices including methods to grow food, conserve water and energy and recycle urban waste. Agriscapes is home of the Farm Store at Kellogg Ranch which sells locally and campus grown foods and products. The Cal Poly Pomona campus also contains a rainforest greenhouse, a California [[ethnobotany]] garden, and an aquatic biology center collectively known as BioTrek, which provides environmental education to all academic levels.{{cite web|url=https://www.csupomona.edu/~biotrek/|title=About BioTrek|publisher=California State Polytechnic University, Pomona|accessdate=2011-03-04}} The entire campus community is served by a free campus shuttle system known as "Bronco Express". The shuttle system comprises 3 lines and is run by the office of Parking & Transportation Services (PTS).{{cite web|url=http://www.dsa.csupomona.edu/parking/maps.asp |title=Bronco Express Shuttle Map|publisher=Dsa.csupomona.edu |date=2009-09-24 |accessdate=2010-04-30}} In addition, PTS also offers a shuttle service known as "BroncoLink" which provides both students and faculty a direct connection from the Pomona North and Downtown Pomona [[Metrolink (Southern California)|Metrolink]] stations to the [[CLA Building]].{{cite web|url=http://www.dsa.csupomona.edu/parking/rideshare.asp?nfid=3863 |title=Rideshare Home |publisher=Dsa.csupomona.edu |date= |accessdate=2010-04-30}} ===Seismic risks and other challenges of campus development=== Although it's believed that the San Jose Fault runs through campus, and geotechnical investigations have been conducted, there is uncertainty regarding its precise [[Fault_(geology)#Fault_types|type]] and location. The CSU Seismic Review Board has classified several buildings on campus as some of the most seismically hazardous in the university system.{{cite journal|last=Pazos|first=Celia S|coauthors=Potter, Hannah; and Polet, Jascha|title=Gravity Profiles across the San Jose Fault on Cal Poly Pomona campus|journal=Abstracts with Programs|publisher=[[Geological Society of America]]|volume=43|issue=2|pages=88|url=http://gsa.confex.com/gsa/2011RM/finalprogram/abstract_187399.htm|accessdate=2011-04-09}} The CLA Building suffers from structural flaws, most notably, water intrusion. In 2005, the university filed a lawsuit against a contractor, for which it was compensated $13.3 million in an out-of-court [[Settlement (litigation)|settlement]].{{cite news|url=http://archrecord.construction.com/news/daily/archives/2010/09/100927predock_cla_building.asp|title=Antoine Predockâs CLA Building in California May Be Demolished|last=Hill|first=David|date=2010-09-27|work=[[Architectural Record]]|accessdate=2011-03-04}} Amid these concerns, on September 2010, the CSU Board of Trustees approved a proposal to have the building razed.{{cite news|url=http://polycentric.csupomona.edu/news_stories/2010/09/csu-proposal-replace-cla.html|title=CSU Approves Proposal to Replace CLA|date=2010-09-22|work=polycentric|accessdate=2011-03-04}} [[Hideo Sasaki]]'s architectural firm ''Sasaki Associates, Inc.'' found in the February 2010 [[Comprehensive planning|master plan]] that the campus's [[seismic risk]], uneven terrain, lack of parking spaces, small classrooms, and pedestrian-unfriendly roads are major constrains for future campus development. It also indicated the lack of identity, an undefined sense of arrival, and a desire to build a stronger on-campus community, among others, as recurrent themes among campus's users. Prior to the ownership shift to Cal Poly SLO in 1938, the Voorhis School for Boys in San Dimas had been providing educational offerings in "music, bookkeeping, agriculture, library work, carpentry, nature study, machine shop, and printing" coupled with [[Christian]] religious fundamentals to an all-men student body comprising poor, underage boys.{{Harvnb|Pflueger|1999|p=42.}} In 1938, the campus became the agricultural branch of Cal Poly SLO when a small staff was transfer from San Luis Obispo along with group of agricultural inspection students.{{Harvnb|Kennedy|2001|p=23.}} Thus, Cal Poly Pomona (then just Cal Poly) began offering [[Associate's degree]]s in 1938 and [[Bachelor's degree]]s in 1940 when, despite legislative opposition from pro-[[University of California]] members in [[Sacramento]], president Julian McPhee asked allied members Armistead B. Carter and Daniel C. Murphy to introduce the bill when two opposing members were not present to vote.{{Harvnb|Kennedy|2001|p=24.}} Following the governance breakup with the San Luis Obispo in 1966, and as outlined by the 1960 [[California Master Plan for Higher Education]], Cal Poly Pomona continued "offer[ing] undergraduate and graduate instruction through the master's degree in the liberal arts and sciences and professional education, including teacher education."{{cite news | title=California State University mission | url=http://www.ucop.edu/acadinit/mastplan/csumission.htm| work= University of California â Office of the President | accessdate=2010-04-25}} Currently, Cal Poly Pomona promotes a "learn by doing" philosophy, where an essential part of the curriculum is hands-on application of knowledge.{{cite news| title=University Vision and Identity Initiative| url=http://www.csupomona.edu/~alumni/docs/focus/meeting/University%20Vision%20and%20Identity%20Presentation.pdf| format=PDF| work= University Advancement Division at Cal Poly Pomona| page=7| accessdate=2008-08-26}} [[Merriam-Webster]] mentions that "polytechnic" is a word first used in 1801 derived from the [[French language|French]] ''[[wikt:polytechnique|polytechnique]]'' which contains the [[Greek language|Greek]]-[[Root (linguistics)|roots]] "poly" (''[[English language|English]]:many'') and "technÄ" (''art''). |} [[File:Student suites at Cal Poly Pomona.png|left|thumb|Residential suites]] With an on-campus housing capacity of 3,600 students, Cal Poly Pomona has the fifth largest housing system in the [[California State University]].{{cite web|url=http://cpp4me.csupomona.edu/|title= Future Students |accessdate=2010-12-05 |work=Cal Poly Pomona}} There are three [[dormitory|residential]] styles on the Pomona campus. The oldest housing facilities consist of six residential halls located on University Drive. The four older red-brick halls are named ''Alamitos'', ''Aliso'', ''Encinitas'', and ''Montecito'', each providing accommodation for up to 212 residents. The other two housing halls (''Cedritos'' and ''Palmitas'') were the result of later housing development and each has room to accommodate up to 185 residents.{{cite web|url=http://www.dsa.csupomona.edu/uhs/res_halls_desc.asp|title= Residence hall descriptions|accessdate=2008-09-15|work=University Housing Services at Cal Poly Pomona}} The two newest residential complexes are the ''Village'' and the ''Suites'' which offer apartment-style living to non-freshman students. The ''Residence Halls'' and the ''Suites'' are managed by the Division of Student Affairs, whereas the ''Village'' is managed by the Cal Poly Pomona Foundation.{{cite web|url=http://foundation.csupomona.edu/village/|title=University Village|work=University Village at Cal Poly Pomona|publisher=Cal Poly Pomona Foundation|accessdate=7 April 2011}} Currently about 52% of first-year students and 12% of all undergraduates live in college housing. While the ''Village'' ''Suites'' are the product of more recent on-campus residential developments. Phase I of the construction of the suites, housing 420 students, completed in 2004 and a second phase is set to open in 2010.{{cite web |url=http://www.csupomona.edu/~fpm/planning/projects/residential_suites.html |title= Residential Suites, Phase I |accessdate=2008-09-15 |work= Cal Poly Pomona}} The total on-campus enrollment is 3,200 (as of 2009),{{cite web|url=http://www.csupomona.edu/future_students.php |title=Cal Poly Pomona |publisher=Csupomona.edu |date= |accessdate=2010-04-30}} but will grow to over 3,822 after the Phase II of the Residential Suites are completely opened in summer 2010,{{cite web|url=http://www.csupomona.edu/~fpm/planning/projects/residential_suites_ph2.html |title=Cal Poly Pomona |publisher=Csupomona.edu |date= |accessdate=2010-04-30}} making it one of the largest student housing programs in the California State University system.{{cite web | url=http://www.csupomona.edu/~publicaffairs/publications/pocketfacts2008.pdf | format=PDF | title= Pocket Facts 2008 | accessdate=2011-03-27 | work=Office of Public Affairs at California State Polytechnic Univeristy, Pomona}} In an effort to reduce commuting and raise academic performance and retention, starting on the 2010-2011 academic year, freshmen from outside the Tier 1 Local Admissions area (the area roughly bounded by the San Gabriel Mountains and Chino Hills to the north and south and the 15 and 605 freeways to the east and west), will be required to live on campus. ===Bronco Student Center=== {{Main|Bronco Student Center}} [[Image:Bronco Student Center.jpg|right|thumb|The [[Bronco Student Center]]]] The Bronco Student Center is a student activity center for meetings, conferences, meals, recreation, and shopping for students and alumni on the campus of Cal Poly Pomona in Pomona, California. This is where ASI student government offices are located, as well as other various student run departments like facilities and operations, Recreation, Programming and Marketing (RPM), Business Services, Games Room Etc. (GRE). ===Campus media=== Campus events are covered by the [[student newspaper]], the ''[[The Poly Post|Poly Post]]''. The Bronco Sports Show is a quarterly television broadcast capturing the highlights and statistics from Bronco Athletics along with other featured events around the campus. ''PolyCentric''{{cite web|url=http://polycentric.csupomona.edu |title=PolyCentric | Cal Poly Pomona |publisher=Polycentric.csupomona.edu |date= |accessdate=2010-04-30}} is the university's official online magazine. PolyCentric features news, announcements of campus events, spotlights on various departments, and resources for faculty and staff. A web site also provides a comprehensive archival search for past articles and photos.{{cite web|url=http://polycentric.csupomona.edu/guide/polycentric-archives.html|title=polycentric Cal Poly Pomona Archives|publisher=Polycentric.csupomona.edu|accessdate=2011-04-09}} ===Bronco Pep Band=== {{Main|Bronco Pep Band}} The Bronco Pep Band is a student-run band at Cal Poly Pomona. The band is a group within the [[Cal Poly Pomona Broncos|athletic department]]. It follows the tradition of other student-run bands in the sense that it focuses on its members individuality. The band attends athletic events during the year to encourage the school's athletic teams and audience support/involvement. The pep band is entirely voluntary and all students at Cal Poly Pomona or anyone else in the area are free to join. ===Greek life=== Greek Life at Cal Poly Pomona consists of 18 fraternities and 11 sororities governed by the Greek Council. From the total male [[Undergraduate education|undergraduate]] population, 2% are enrolled in fraternities and 1% of women in soroties respectively. [[Sigma Nu]], [[Sigma Chi]] and [[Phi Kappa Tau]] are three fraternities with off-campus chapter houses.{{cite web|url=http://collegeprowler.com/cal-poly-pomona/greek-life/|title=Cal Poly Pomona - Greek Life|publisher=[[College Prowler]]|accessdate=2010-09-02}}{{cite web|url=http://www.dsa.csupomona.edu/osl/greeklife/default.asp|title=Welcome to Greek Life at Cal Poly Pomona|publisher=California State Polytechnic University, Pomona|accessdate=2011-03-04}}{{cite web|url=http://www.sigmanupomona.com/chapter-history|title=Chapter History|publisher=Sigma Nu Fraternity|accessdate=11 April 2011}} ===Rose Parade float=== {{Main|Cal Poly Universities Rose Float}} Cal Poly Pomona together with [[California Polytechnic State University|Cal Poly San Luis Obispo]] has participated in the [[Tournament of Roses Parade|Tournament of Roses parade]] since 1949; winning the Award of Merit in their first year. In the period from 1949â2005, the floats have won 44 awards. This joint program is one of the longest consecutive running self-built entries in the parade, as well as the only "self built" floats designed and constructed entirely by students year-round on both campuses. The Rose Float tradition continues today and marks the partnership between the two Cal Poly campuses. ==Athletics== {{Main|Cal Poly Pomona Broncos}} ===Voorhis Vikings=== Before the university moved from San Dimas to Pomona, the college had a handful of athletic teams named the '''"Voorhis Vikings"'''. They were composed mostly of homeless and orphaned boys of all races who were cared for at the Voorhis School during the ten-year period it operated.{{cite web | title=Special Collections & University Archives-Voorhis Vikings | url=http://www.csupomona.edu/~library/specialcollections/voorhis/vikings/index.html | work= University Library at California State Polytechnic University, Pomona| accessdate=2010-04-26}} Despite this historical background, the university's current athletic programs are named the Broncos. ===Cal Poly Pomona Broncos=== Cal Poly Pomona [[varsity team]]s compete in the [[California Collegiate Athletic Association]] of [[Division II (NCAA)|NCAA Division II]].
